column4:
With all the hurricane activity in the Atlantic Basin, Canadians are wondering if climate change is to blame. 

Meteorologists from the Canadian Hurricane Centre at Environment and Climate Change Canada see a difference in storm projections. Climate change may have a variety of impacts on hurricanes, such as stronger winds and more rain. Be prepared!
column9:
The report from the Hurricane Center made no mention of the cause of global warming, yet we are again being shouted at about the "hoax", and how warming has nothing to do with human greenhouse gas emissions. 
Don Easterbrook is a geologist, not a climate scientist, and his prediction of cooling in this decade is way off, so far.

column4: All her life, Katharine McLennan nurtured a deep passion and commitment towards the history and preservation of the Fortress of Louisbourg in Cape Breton, where she was from. For years, she did extensive research to help tell the story of Louisbourg, and, after World War I, she was at the forefront of a civil group aiming to preserve the Fortress of Louisbourg site. Their work led to the opening of the Louisbourg Museum in 1936 and the partial reconstruction of the Fortress in the 1960s. Katharine was named "Honorary Curator" of the museum and served in this capacity for over twenty years. #EqualityMatters #InternationalWomensDay

column4:
Why study animal guts? Because their microbial communities play a role in digestion. By learning more about how microbes assist in digestion, scientists could improve farm animals‚Äô ability to digest food and grow faster and stronger.

Because of the importance of digestion to growth, AAFC researchers are involved with several projects related to the microbiota in the guts of animals. Two are particularly interesting, because they focus on the guts of animals you might not think have much to do with agriculture: beavers and pandas. http://ow.ly/wxgU30fW2HS

column4:
Is there a more magical place on earth than Nahanni National Park Reserve? We might be biased, but we don‚Äôt think so! Nahanni National Park Reserve is considered a paradise for those adventurers who pursue remote wilderness. Alpinists are drawn to the Cirque of Unclimbables, paddlers explore the heart of the reserve and mountaineers trek, compass in hand, across range, meadow and karst. Interpreters located within the park convey the Dene culture to the curious. Want to learn more?  http://www.pc.gc.ca/en/pn-np/nt/nahanni

To celebrate #Canada150, we're featuring ALL of our 200+ places across our social media accounts. Stay tuned!

column4:
Atlantic Canada is currently seeing an outbreak of Trichomonosis. It is a bird parasite that affects the upper digestive tract of birds, limiting their ability to swallow and keep their food down. 

Although bird feeders and baths make it easier for us to watch birds in their natural habitat, they can be harmful during an outbreak. You can help slow down the spread of Trichomonosis by removing bird feeders and baths and following  these simple steps: 

BIRD FEEDERS AND BATHS
1) Take down your bird feeders and bird baths. During the summer, there is enough natural food available, so there is no need to worry. 
2) Wash them thoroughly with a weak bleach solution (5% sodium hypochlorite).
3) Dispose of any wet or exposed feed left around your bird feeders and baths.
4) Refrain from putting them back in your yard until the cooler temperatures in the Fall.

For more information on Trichomonosis: http://ow.ly/Qr7y30dZhU9
column9: Inquires can be made to the Canadian Wildlife Health Cooperative, to find out if there is an outbreak in your province. http://ow.ly/CviN30e7ob3 [[SHARE]]

On the drier east slopes of the Rocky Mountains, buffaloberry is most common, and on the moister west slopes of the Rockies blueberry and huckleberry shrubs grow. See our website for tips on being bear aware: http://ow.ly/nPMU30ct438
